learning_outcomes.description: Develop a deep understanding of the critical issues faced in Australian Animal Production systems
Process and critically analyse scientific publications in a specific area of animal production science.
Effectively communicate via a presentation your knowledge on a specific topic related to Animal Production Science.
Apply critical reasoning to issues in animal production through independent thought and informed judgement.

assessments.assessment_title: Advanced Study in Animal Production Science 1 - Fact sheet
assessments.task_description:
You are to select ONE topic from the following three to conduct BOTH assignment 1 (Fact sheet) and 2 (Oral Presentation).

Topics are:

  1. Sustainability and the carbon footprint of livestock production
  2. Social licence and ethics of livestock production
  3. Precision technology and smart farming in livestock production


Assignment 1. Industry Fact sheet

Word length: Maximum 2 x A4 pages, size 12 Times New Roman font, single spaced, normal border


After selecting one topic, you will conduct your own research to gain a deeper understanding of the topic. You task is then to create a two-page fact sheet suitable to be given to industry members (i.e. livestock producers) outlining the topic. The exact content you include is up to you – but as a guideline you can consider including importance of the topic, any issues associated with it, and/or any benefits. 

Consider your audience when drafting the text, ensuring your ideas are clearly articulated. The use of figures and images is encouraged.


There are a number of journals you can use to explore these topic areas such as: Animal Frontiers, Journal of Animal Science, Production Animal Science, Animals, Animal, International Journal of Biometeorology, Journal of Dairy Science – there are more!

Resources will be available on the course Blackboard site on how to construct industry fact sheets.

Scientific journal articles are to be used for the assignment – as a guide, >10 scientific articles should be used. You are not to use more than three (3) website "articles" for the assignment and any website resources should be from reputable organisations.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your fact sheet in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Advanced Study in Animal Production Science 2 - Oral presentation
assessments.task_description:
Using the topic you selected for assignment 1 - Industry fact sheet (listed below), you are to prepare a 10 min presentation discussing the topic.

Topics are:

  1. Sustainability and the carbon footprint of livestock production
  2. Social licence and ethics of livestock production
  3. Precision technology and smart farming in livestock production


The presentation will be given in-person, and you will be expected to answer 2-3 questions following your talk.

Students will be assessed on both their presentation and their responses during question time. Additionally, active participation is required; you are expected to listen to all peer presentations and contribute by asking questions when you are not presenting.

This assessment will also be peer marked, meaning each student will complete a grading sheet for every presentation, and provide comments to the presenter.


The talk should have 1 slide per minute, with an additional slide for the title slide, and reference slide. Peer-reviewed literature and/or authoritative industry reports should be the source of information - all of which must be cited throughout, with a reference list as the final slide.

To ensure your slides enhance rather than distract from your talk, avoid reading text verbatim and provide clear explanations for every diagram.


The presentation should be structured as follows:

 1. Introduction and Scope (3 marks, 1 minute)

  • Clearly identify the selected topic.
  • Define key terms and explain the relevance of the issue to modern livestock production.
  • State the central argument or position of the presentation.


2. Core Analysis of Selected Topic (18 marks, 6 minutes)

Students should tailor this section to their chosen topic making sure to include critical appraisal, limitations, and contrasting perspectives.

 

3. Implications and Integration (9 marks, 3 minutes)

Discuss implications for:

  • Industry practice
  • Policy or regulation
  • Future research


4.Question time (5 marks, 2 mins)


A rubric will be posted to BB.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your presentation slides in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
End of semester exam will assess all lecture content throughout semester.

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in person. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

The lecture series will cover the topics listed under the sub-activities. Please refer to the course blackboard site for the full details. List of activities below is subject to change.


Sub-activity: Week 1 - Course Introduction (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 2 - Health module 1. Acidosis (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 3 - Health module 2. Disease case studies (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 4 - Assessment info session - NO LECTURE (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 5 - Health module 3. Small ruminant parasites (Dr Anne Beasley) Week 6 - Products module 1. Ruminant products (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 7 - Products module 2. Monogastric products (A/Prof Elham Soumeh) Week 8 - Products module 3. Alternatives to Animal Products (A/Prof Sarah Meale) Week 9 - Production module 1. Efficiency and Nitrogen recycling (Morteza Moradi) Week 10 - Production module 2. Intro to genetics (Dr Christie Warburton) Week 11 - Production module 3. Epigenetics (Dr Christie Warburton)
